And you are right about Bruce Ohr and Christopher Steele. I mean, Steele is on the payroll of Hillary Clinton and the FBI and when they fire him for being a liar, they continue to use him in violation of FBI regulations. They were devious about it. They had Bruce Ohr as a conduit. And the other amazing thing is even after the President is elected, after he takes office, and for several months afterwards, they are still using Christopher Steele as a spy on Donald Trump, trying to verify the unverifiable dossier.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: And now the big discussion is about this Trump Tower meeting, gentlemen, and the allegation is that this meeting between Don, Jr. and this Russian woman amounted to some kind of conspiracy. They do not use were collusion, I guess the legal terminology would be conspiracy because information is the same thing as money, but I am looking at it and no information was ever given to the Trump team by Russia, yet, the Hillary Clinton campaign paid for information from Kremlin sources. They just washed it through an intermediary, Christopher Steele. Isn't there a big difference between the Trump Tower meeting and the way that the dossier was obtained, Dan?

utterances.speaker: BONGINO
utterances.utterance: You know, Jesse, you just hit the nail on the head. Jonathan Turley does a lot of work on this network who is a very skilled lawyer and not partisan by any stretch, wrote a terrific piece saying just that. There is no possible way that the Trump Tower meeting between Don Trump, Jr., Manafort and a couple of Russians who by the way, have very deep connections to both the Clintons and Fusion GPS -- that's another story -- where no significant information on the Clintons is exchanged whatsoever. Granted, the meeting is a bad idea. Everybody acknowledges that, okay? There is no way that's a crime, but as you just said, Hillary Clinton who actually paid, Jesse -- paid Kremlin connected sources for actual information that was changed, that did change it. There is no way -- that is not a crime. I mean this is basic logic. The Democrats are going down the road here, I will tell you, Jesse. They are walking right off a cliff and I don't even think they know it. They are blinded by their hatred for Trump.

utterances.speaker: GARRETT
utterances.utterance: You know the Federal Campaign Election Act specifically says, you can go to the FEC website, it says, "Foreign nationals may volunteer their services in American political campaigns." Any information by itself is not a thing of value which would violate the law. What is a thing of value, and by the way, information not a thing of value, money is Hillary Clinton paid money to Christopher Steele making that a thing of value. So she clearly violated the law and egregious cases, like hers, it's a crime. But the Trump Tower meeting with Donald Trump, Jr., that's not even remotely a crime.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: But you know what guys, I don't want to lock Hillary up, and you want to know why? I want her to run again. 2020, let's get a rematch. Guys, thank you very much and everybody go get Gregg's book. Candace Owens becomes the latest target of Antifa. She is here to react, next. The uncivil left out of control again, as two more conservatives were attacked this week by Antifa protesters, so watch what happens to Candace Owens and Charlie Kirk when they just wanted to have some breakfast in Philly on Monday.

utterances.speaker: GROUP
utterances.utterance: [Inaudible] [bleep].

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: And don't forget all of these vicious attacks have been encouraged by Democratic Congresswoman, Maxine Waters.

utterances.speaker: MAXINE WATERS, US CONGRESSWOMAN, CALIFORNIA, DEMOCRAT
utterances.utterance: If you see anybody from that Cabinet in a restaurant, in a department store, at a gasoline station, you get out and you create a crowd and you push back on them and you tell them, they are not welcome anymore, anywhere.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Joining me now, Communications Director for Turning Point USA, Candace Owens. So, Candace do you hold Maxine Waters personally responsible for those people coming after you during breakfast?

utterances.speaker: CANDACE OWENS, COMMUNICATIONS DIRECTOR, TURNING POINT USA
utterances.utterance: I hold Maxine Waters responsible as well as all of the politicians who did not speak out and say that this was wrong. They all remain silent because they are okay with this because Antifa is their gang, okay, they condone this behavior all the time. We are seeing that it is increasing. It has happened over and over again it is getting more vicious each time that it happens.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: So you believe that Antifa is indirectly linked to the Democratic Party leadership?

utterances.speaker: OWENS
utterances.utterance: I bet if we did something, they would be directly linked to the Democratic community.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Do you think maybe money is involved or you think people are involved and maybe their mere silence publicly encourages this type of behavior? Or even more so behind the scenes?

utterances.speaker: OWENS
utterances.utterance: Absolutely. Just so people understand watching, this was 8:00 a.m. on a Monday morning. All of you guys were able to magically get out of work and dressed in Antifa gear or this is your job?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: How did they know you guys were having breakfast there?

utterances.speaker: OWENS
utterances.utterance: So we actually were eating in the caf, and four Antifa members walked in like they were not there to harass us, and when they recognized us, they kept looking back and texting on their phones. We didn't not think they were going to assemble an army. We thought that we could ask to get through breakfast and respectfully disagree on politics without saying anything to one another, but no, they sent out the bat signal and this is what happened.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: So you guys had someone filming this encounter. Is that where the video is from?

utterances.speaker: OWENS
utterances.utterance: That is correct. We actually had one of our production assistants who were there because we were all about to go into a meeting and we told her to mainly start filming because if we do not have evidence, they were going to make up an entire story about what happened, so we needed to film every single moment and we're glad we did.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: And the media is whining about the potential violence that is going to become because of President Trump's rhetoric when there is actual violence taking place against Trump supporters. So when you're being attacked like that on the street, do you have an understanding that it is happening because of your effectiveness with the freethinker movement?

utterances.speaker: OWENS
utterances.utterance: One hundred percent it is. They know exactly who I am and they feel that they are losing control. They've had a major hold on black thought for so long. I came around -- I am not the only one, but I think my approach and my style is a little bit different. My communication style is a little bit different and I've been tremendously affected by getting people to consider different ideas, conservative positions, free markets, capitalism. They don't like me.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: They see you as a threat that is why they are harassing you.

utterances.speaker: OWENS
utterances.utterance: One hundred percent. They view me as a threat. That's been very clear, that's why they show up when Charlie and I are on campus and we're speaking, and it's why Black Lives Matter protesters come up because we know the real stats, we know what's going on and we are going to make sure that every black person in America is educated so that they know never to let the Democratic Party to use us again to do their bidding.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I know you want to talk about something else we found interesting about police brutality against black people. We have some startling statistics. In 2018, just already, 34 police officers have been shot and killed, okay? Now, in 2018, I think so far only 13 unarmed black Americans have been killed by police. So there's a little bit of a discrepancy almost twice as many police officers have been killed than police have killed unarmed black Americans. What do you make of those statistics?

utterances.speaker: OWENS
utterances.utterance: I've known these statistics for a very long time and that is why I attempt to reeducate the black community about what is actually going on. A police officer is 18.5 times more likely to be shot and killed by a black man than the other way around and that is why I vocally support the police. I understand what they're up against. I would never make an excuse and say it's okay when an unarmed black is shot by a police officer, but I do understand that those statistics are skewed in an effort to make black people hate the police officers and do the bidding for the Democratic Party which I refuse to do.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: And some startling statistics came out from the Rasmussen poll, this isn't getting enough play, I think the black support for President Trump was about 15%, maybe a year or a year and a half ago, and now it is at 29%. Who do you attribute that to?

utterances.speaker: OWENS
utterances.utterance: I think there been so many people, black conservatives that are standing up and speaking out finally. We're definitely no longer afraid. And I think that I'm encouraged by seeing all of these YouTubers that speak out and the one person we can credit for this is President Donald Trump. Thank you for all of the tremendous work that you have done to get our community off of their feet and to give us jobs again. Unemployment is at an all-time low. You are the man and we love you and we will support you.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: What about Kanye? Does Kanye get any credit for that?

utterances.speaker: OWENS
utterances.utterance: Kanye gets the credit. He does -- he broke the window on culture and it made it okay for people to discuss it because so many people weren't paying attention. Kanye found that MAGA hat, thank you, Kanye West! Number two.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: All right Donald with the help of Kanye. Candace, thank you very much.

utterances.speaker: OWENS
utterances.utterance: Thanks for having me.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Up next, a professor attempts to school me on masculinity and later, mini therapy horses.

utterances.speaker: MARIANNE RAFFERTY, CORRESPONDENT, FOX NEWS
utterances.utterance: Live from "America's News Headquarters," I'm Marianne Rafferty. We are learning more about the theft of a passenger plane that caused a major scare over Seattle. Authorities identifying the suspect as a 29-year-old employee of Horizon Air who had security clearance, but no pilot's license. Police say he was suicidal when he stole an empty turboprop plane and took it on an hour-long joyride while being chased by fighter jets. The suspect eventually crashing onto a nearby island, killing himself. The FBI is investigating his possible motive. In Charlottesville, Virginia, marking one year since a white nationalist rally turned deadly. This is the scene from last year when one person died and dozens of others injured. Virginia's governor bracing for any possible protests declaring a state of emergency, also ramping up the city's police presence. I am Marianne Rafferty. Now back to "Watters' World."

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: What kind of characteristics do you think toxic masculinity manifests itself as?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.utterance: Violence, aggression, sexual assault, whatever the need to show dominance and power.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Would you admit that men maybe men are physically superior?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.utterance: No, absolutely not. I bet I could beat you in any physical competition.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: How much can you bench press?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.utterance: More than you.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: All across the country, toxic masculinity courses are taking colleges by storm. And now the new school here in New York will be holding a class called "Male Melancholia: Crisis Masculinity," which focuses on the fall of white masculinity. Masha Tupitsyn is a Professor of Film and Gender Studies who teaches the course, and she joins me now. All right, professor, what is toxic masculinity first of all?

utterances.speaker: MASHA TUPITSYN IS A PROFESSOR OF FILM AND GENDER STUDIES
utterances.utterance: I mean, I would say there are different ways to describe it, but the way I refer to it is to think about toxic masculinity as when masculinity has to kind of abuse its power in order to function.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: How would I demonstrate on a day-to-day basis, toxic masculinity?

utterances.speaker: TUPITSYN
utterances.utterance: Well, I mean, I think it's -- that's the complicated question, but on a daily basis it would be in your relationships with other people and your relationships with women in the workplace and the way that you relate to your own power in the workplace and your daily life.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Just by being a jerk and offensive and imposing my will on other people?

utterances.speaker: TUPITSYN
utterances.utterance: Yes or even negotiating that imposition of will on other people. All right, this idea that you have to kind of stoke my ego or behave a certain way to get ahead.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Okay so, white masculinity, is now a problem. There is a downfall among white males? How so?

utterances.speaker: TUPITSYN
utterances.utterance: Well, I'm not saying that there's a downfall. I don't think there is a loss of power although men are always lamenting their loss of power.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: How are we doing that?

utterances.speaker: TUPITSYN
utterances.utterance: I think one of the -- well this constant idea even someone like President Trump who is always lamenting sort of the good old days or a show like "Madmen" which is always focusing on this kind of loss of supremacy that men once held. So that narrative has been going on and that's ...

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: And so when Donald Trump says "Make America Great Again," what is he trying to say? That we want to return to the gold days where white men ruled the earth?

utterances.speaker: TUPITSYN
utterances.utterance: Yes and still rule the earth, but that is being destabilized and so there is this constant kind of narrative of mourning and loss about what's been lost. But what really needs to happen ..

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: But couldn't the president just be saying, "I want to go back to the '80s where the economy was roaring and we were doing great?"

utterances.speaker: TUPITSYN
utterances.utterance: And when he was the king.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I mean, couldn't that be what he is saying? Maybe not about ...

utterances.speaker: TUPITSYN
utterances.utterance: But either way, it is self-referential.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: ... white males may be more about let's go back to when America was strong and powerful and the economy was great.

utterances.speaker: TUPITSYN
utterances.utterance: And it was a patriarchy that no one questioned.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: But is he saying there was a patriarchy that no one questioned? Or is that something you're saying?

utterances.speaker: TUPITSYN
utterances.utterance: But no one has to say that. We already -- I think there isn't any debate anymore whether sexism is real. I think even the disbelievers are now believers.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: So you think when Trump says "make America great again," he wants to go back to the time when sexism was good?

utterances.speaker: TUPITSYN
utterances.utterance: Well, when it was good and it certainly was not questioned and people were afraid to question it.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: But how do you know that?

utterances.speaker: TUPITSYN
utterances.utterance: Part of -- let me just finish. So part of what I think is important about the #MeToo Movement or the TimesUp Movement is that it is making everyone question what the effects of masculinity have been, right? It is making everyone have that conversation and to think about how sexism has been totally normalized just on a everyday level.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: But how do you know though? Because you don't know.

utterances.speaker: TUPITSYN
utterances.utterance: Well, I am also -- I am a woman and sexism is part of the daily fabric of all women's lives.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Okay, but you don't know when Trump says make America great again, he is talking about wanting to bring back sexism.

utterances.speaker: TUPITSYN
utterances.utterance: So now, we're having a conversation about mind reading as opposed to interpretation.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: No, but you brought that up he wanted to go back to those days.

utterances.speaker: TUPITSYN
utterances.utterance: Because these are very old narratives and they don't just refer to national politics. National politics also consists of race and class and gender. It's a kind of packaged deal, right, when you're talking about nation building, you're talking about a lot of others, it is multidimensional things.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Okay, listen, I did not take that from what the President said when he uses that slogan. I guess you're interpreting it...

utterances.speaker: TUPITSYN
utterances.utterance: But I didn't come here to ...

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: So what do white men need to do in America now? How can we improve in your opinion?

utterances.speaker: TUPITSYN
utterances.utterance: Well, to me, the crisis is really about the lack of responsibility and this lack of self interrogation, right, that's really what -- I mean etymologically, the root of crisis means this point at which change must come.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: But do you mean ...

utterances.speaker: TUPITSYN
utterances.utterance: So the either the change can come or it won't, but what had needs to happen is that when men start doing some the work and interrogation around masculinity as opposed all of these other sort of special interest groups who study ...

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Okay, so let's just study it step-by-step. I'm a man, I'm a white man. What do I need to ask myself or what do I need to address internally about my white male?

utterances.speaker: TUPITSYN
utterances.utterance: Well, I would say two things to start with, so one is what kind of privileges have I inherited because of my whiteness and my straight masculinity, I would say?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: White privilege.

utterances.speaker: TUPITSYN
utterances.utterance: White privilege but it also has to do masculinity, so I would ask -- and we all have to ask that question. What privileges do we come into the world with and do we abuse those privileges? The second question.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Okay, you want white men -- just take a step back, you want white men to recognize that they have certain advantages by being born a white straight man?

utterances.speaker: TUPITSYN
utterances.utterance: Yes, that they use.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: And use and I, as a white, straight male should be more conscious of my privileges when I go walk around in everyday society?

utterances.speaker: TUPITSYN
utterances.utterance: You should be but most likely you won't be because you don't have to. I mean, that's sort of the argument that I am making. Most people are only conscious because they are disenfranchised in some way, right? So they are aware of how the dominant power works and how their own lives function, and people who have dominant power don't have to ask those questions. So the questions that men have to ask themselves are the same questions that all kind of people that are struggling for consciousness and liberation and justice need to ask so that the world can be better for everyone.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: What about a guy in Minnesota who is making $20.00 an hour. It's a really tough job. He's got a family he's trying to support and the economy is not working for him and things are tough. How does he have white privilege?

utterances.speaker: TUPITSYN
utterances.utterance: Well, you did not specify that he is white, not everybody has white privilege. He still is -- even if he does not have economic privilege, right? I'm saying ...

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: You're saying this guy has racial privilege.

utterances.speaker: TUPITSYN
utterances.utterance: He still has racial privilege. He still has masculine privilege. He can walk into a bar and behave a certain way because he is a man, that he might not be able to walk into his job and behave that way. We all kind of negotiate power in different ways, so just because you're not powerful in one setting you can still be powerful and privileged in another setting.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: So, when I walk into a bar as a straight white male, am I being too confident when I walk into the bar? Or should I go in a more humble way?

utterances.speaker: TUPITSYN
utterances.utterance: But then I do not how you are when you walk into a bar. I just know that men can behave a certain way in public settings and in bars that is different from women. I mean, this is the case for everyone, right? There are codes that we are all following. Even if we just go to work and we don't behave a certain way, we get fired.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Like I can be loud and obnoxious and I can buy people drinks ...

utterances.speaker: TUPITSYN
utterances.utterance: And sexually aggressive.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: ... and I could flirt with people, is that what you're saying?

utterances.speaker: TUPITSYN
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: And women can't do that?

utterances.speaker: TUPITSYN
utterances.utterance: Well, they might do it, but they pay a different price for it. Even just on the level of you might not be seen as someone desperate if you're a single man that walks into a bar, whereas if a woman walks into a bar and she is single, that is perceived as a very different kind of social gesture.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: And then lastly, what was the other question I am supposed to ask myself as a straight white male?

utterances.speaker: TUPITSYN
utterances.utterance: Well, you've interrupted me so many times, and now, I can't remember.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I guess that's probably my toxic masculinity.

utterances.speaker: TUPITSYN
utterances.utterance: Probably.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: All right, professor, thank you very much. I really appreciate it.

utterances.speaker: TUPITSYN
utterances.utterance: Thank you for having me.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Coming up, Diamond and Silk take on Rosie O'Donnell. I can't wait for this. Violence in Chicago out of control. Last weekend, 74 people were shot across the city; 12 of them were killed. President Trump has expressed deep concern over the escalating violence, but Rahm Emanuel, the city's ultraliberal mayor, told him to butt out.

utterances.speaker: STEPHEN COLBERT, HOST, CBS
utterances.utterance: You recently declared Chicago schools a Trump free zone.

utterances.speaker: RAHM EMANUEL, MAYOR OF CHICAGO
utterances.utterance: The city of Chicago, yeah.

utterances.speaker: COLBERT
utterances.utterance: The whole thing?

utterances.speaker: EMANUEL
utterances.utterance: The whole thing is Trump free. I don't know if I've ever thought this but I did yesterday, can you actually take away a president's security clearance?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Rahm, someone has got to control the city. It is totally out of control. Almost 4,000 people have been murdered in Chicago since you took office. Look at the statistics. Here with reaction, Diamond and Silk. All right, ladies, what you think about Rahm and this massive amount of violence going on there?

utterances.speaker: DIAMOND, VIDEO BLOGGER
utterances.utterance: You know, first of all, let me just say this here, I think that the President should send in the Feds. Because you can't have this level of violence, turf wars and drugs going through that city without somebody being paid and kickback paddy whack, give a dog a bone to turn a blind eye.

utterances.speaker: SILK, VIDEO BLOGGER
utterances.utterance: That's right.

utterances.speaker: DIAMOND
utterances.utterance: The first thing he should do is send in the Feds and then send in the National Guards to clean up that place. You know, I think it is so sad that we have black on black crime, people getting caught in the cross fires of bullets and being killed for no reason, innocent. Innocent blood. And where is the Al Sharptons, the Jesse Jackson, the NAACP?

utterances.speaker: SILK
utterances.utterance: And the NFL players.

utterances.speaker: DIAMOND
utterances.utterance: And the NFL players -- to kneel and talk to our black brothers and tell them to stop killing each other. Where are they at? They are nowhere to be found. But if this just happened to white people, here come everybody, going against -- going into the situation to see how we can solve it. It is time for us to pay attention to what's going on. What is going on? This is a black on black crime. This is our black men killing other black men and innocent people getting caught in the cross fires and it needs to stop.

utterances.speaker: SILK
utterances.utterance: And this is also a clear example of what Democratic ran cities look like. You have individuals like this particular mayor that would prefer to fund sanctuary cities instead of fund individuals to help clean up the city.

utterances.speaker: DIAMOND
utterances.utterance: That's right.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: It is a national disgrace and the mainstream media is not even holding Rahm Emanuel accountable. A lot of other news stories this past week and the last couple of weeks the media has just completely buried. So, the other day the President goes down to Florida and announces a massive increase in jobs as a result of his policies down there. We also saw the remains of the Korean War soldiers returned. And look at this here, Pence comes out to receive the remains in a very somber and important and historical ceremony. And look at the networks. ABC News did not even give it 30 seconds. CBS did not cover it. NBC Nightly News did not cover it. MSNBC did not take it live. I mean, it is just completely ridiculous the way that they are burying these types of stories. And then you had another really poignant moment where the President stops his motorcade after one of these events and gets out and starts greeting firefighters and shaking their hands. It was just one of those really touching, Presidential moments that the media, if it had been Barack Obama, would have picked up and led with on the nightly news, but if it's this President, they don't even cover it at all.

utterances.speaker: DIAMOND
utterances.utterance: You know, unlike other people that probably didn't vote for the president, we voted for this man because of this reason. We know it is hard, he loves people and that should be shown on national news, but they don't do that because they like to disrespect him and disparage him. That's the kind of narrative that they like to run on this president. Instead of giving him praise for the good things that he's doing, he's doing things that we've never seen done in our country before, but they don't want to give him the credit for that. What they want to do is stay on their own stinking thinking narrative.

utterances.speaker: SILK
utterances.utterance: That's right.

utterances.speaker: DIAMOND
utterances.utterance: And that is why we ignore them. We really appreciate this president for everything that he is doing for this country.

utterances.speaker: SILK
utterances.utterance: That's right.

utterances.speaker: DIAMOND
utterances.utterance: And that why I tell you, when you bet on Trump, when you vote for Trump you never can go wrong with that.

utterances.speaker: SILK
utterances.utterance: And we love our President so, so much that we wish he could be the President forever.

utterances.speaker: DIAMOND
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: You have to change the Constitution for that one, ladies.

utterances.speaker: SILK
utterances.utterance: Well, let's get started with it.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Okay, so Rosie O'Donnell does not want him to be President forever. She wants him impeached immediately. She did a round of media interviews. Here she is on a cable network.

utterances.speaker: ROSIE O'DONNELL, AMERICAN ACTRESS
utterances.utterance: I believe that Trump is loathed in America, that people are embarrassed and ashamed of who he is and that come election day, we are going to stand up at the polls and let him know, and unless he goes in and has the Russians kind of fix it like he did last time in 2016, we are going to see him gone.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Ladies, what to think about Rosie O'Donnell making a comeback?

utterances.speaker: DIAMOND
utterances.utterance: Rosie don't realize that the American people also feel dislike and disdain for her, too.

utterances.speaker: SILK
utterances.utterance: That's right.

utterances.speaker: DIAMOND
utterances.utterance: And maybe she should do what she told everybody she was going to do is go, and instead of her sitting in front of the White House, what she should've been doing while sitting in that jailhouse for a violation of giving too much campaign contribution to all of these people under alias names.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: That's right.

utterances.speaker: DIAMOND
utterances.utterance: That's what she should be worried about.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I forgot about that. I forgot about that.

utterances.speaker: DIAMOND
utterances.utterance: ... well, see, I remembered it.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yea, you have a better memory than I do. I don't think the Feds are probably going to make her a priority. All right, I will see you next week. Up next, Greg Gutfeld and I share our favorite Trump tweets of the year. Be right back. President Trump known for his tough tweets and stinging comments about liberals. So we thought, we'd highlight a few of our favorites from 2018. Here with his picks, host of "The Greg Gutfeld Show," and author of the new book, the "Gutfeld Monologues," Greg Gutfeld.

utterances.speaker: GREG GUTFELD, HOST, THE GREG GUTFELD SHOW
utterances.utterance: What do you think of my shirt?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I love that shirt.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I knew what you were up to, you were going to have me on to talk about Trump so you could beat me in the ratings on Saturday, tonight, and I though, I'm going to counteract your deviousness which is by the way, brilliant to do a Trump segment with me, to beat me on Saturday night. So I thought I'd wear this shirt.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I like it. It needs a collar, everything else is great through.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Of course, and flip it up. So, I could flip it up. By the way, I look great, don't I?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: You do look great.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I've lost some weight.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Did you just come back from the gym?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I went to -- that's where I got this idea, but I've been working out a lot just for you, Jesse.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes, you look fantastic.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Now, that you are on the show, I have to keep up. I have to start watching my weight, I might even dye my hair.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Well, you don't need to. You don't need to. You look fantastic and everybody knows it. We are going to read some Trump tweets.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Here is my favorite one. You ready? "The Red Hen Restaurant should focus more on cleaning its filthy canopies, doors and windows. Badly needs a paint job. Rather than refusing to serve a fine person like Sarah Huckabee Sanders. I always had a rule, if a restaurant is dirty on the outside, it is dirty on the inside."

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: It is one of the best because it is specific; filthy canopies. That should be the name of a boat.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Filthy canopies. You know, he was a restaurateur. He's got all of these famous places all over the country. He does take pride in the cleanliness and the display and the presentation of a restaurant, and nothing is worse than calling a restaurant filthy.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: It's also memorable. People, when they think of a restaurant as dirty, they can't get that out of their head.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes, because you are a very picky eater. You'd never go to the Red Hen.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I eat nothing but raw pigeon.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: That's disgusting. I punched a pigeon once. Didn't hit it though. All right, Greg, read one of your favorite Trump tweets from this year.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: "While Washington, Michigan was a big success, Washington, DC just did not work. Everyone is want to talk about the fact that the White House Correspondents Dinner was a very big boring bust. The so-called comedian really "bombed." Greg Gutfeld should host next year @PeteHegseth."

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Wait, so I wonder why you picked that tweet.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I don't know. You know, the thing is it's really weird to wake up in the morning and have a lot of people going, "Hey, did you look on Twitter?"

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes, your phone blows up.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes, and I go, "Oh, that's good." But you know, I was very touched, and I think he's right, but I don't know if I would do the gig.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Why not?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: You know what? You never leave the gig better off than you were before. You know what I mean?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: It just doesn't help.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: It doesn't help and your jokes probably would go over all of their heads and they ...

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I think you are right.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Your humor is a little too high brow for those people. All right, one of my other favorites from this year is this. "Crazy Joe Biden is trying to act like a tough guy. Actually he is weak, both mentally and physically and yet, he threatens me for the second time with physical assault. He doesn't know me. But he would go down fast and hard, crying all the way. Don't threaten people, Joe." What a tough guy.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: He is a natural at this. This is an art form. "Don't threaten people, Joe" should be a t-shirt. It would be fantastic.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes, like yours.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: He's good at this. I know.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes, you should make I'm one. I like that he is going to go down fast and hard. Like Trump has been training. Those two guys. All right, go ahead, what's your next one?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: My next one, "The media are good news fire extinguishers. @greggutfeld, @TheFive.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I actually agree with that one. That was a very good line, and you just said that a couple of days ago.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes, I did and he quoted me, so I thought I'd do this as trying to make it all about me and "The Greg Gutfeld Show" which will be on in less than 90 minutes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: You know, I finally met someone more shameless than myself.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes, yes. It's true and we're both here at the same table.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: That's right.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: A double dose of shamelessness.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Okay, here we go. Next one. This is the last one for me. "Alec Baldwin," actually calls him "Alex ..."

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Perfect.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: "... whose dying mediocre career was saved by his impersonation of me on SNL now says playing DJT was agony for him. Alex, it was also agony for those who were forced to watch. You are terrible. Bring back Darrell Hammond, much funnier and a far greater talent."

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: You know what's great about this?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: What's that?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: The mistake he makes is on purpose, Alex Baldwin ...

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Do you think that was not a typo?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes, it was on purpose. It was just another little dig, like, I don't even know the guy's name.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: It's Alex, Alec -- it doesn't matter, he's washed up.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: That's like, like Max Gutfeld.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes, exactly. There might be one of those.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Probably. What's your last one here?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Let's see, "The Gutfeld Monologues is the greatest book ever written with the exception of "The Art of the Deal" which is also a great gift for all ages."

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Wait a second ...

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: No, it hasn't happened. That tweet has not happened. I just made that up. I made up a tweet.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: You're perpetuating fake news on "Watters' World."

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I'm planting the thought in the president's head to tweet this, and then my book sales will skyrocket.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: But you want a link in the tweet. That should be.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes, I've got to beat Jeanine and I've got to beat and Jarrett -- Gregg Jarrettand Jeanine.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Listen, as long as everybody sells, one, two, three, we're all fine.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Thanks.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: We don't compete on this show -- at all. All right, so other favorite moments, that I've selected, Greg's selections were really not up to par.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: That's true.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: One of my favorite moments was when the president was with Kim Jong-un and just a great embarrassing moment for the North Korean leader. Watch this.

utterances.speaker: DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES
utterances.utterance: Hurry guys, getting a great picture of everybody, shall we have a nice and handsome ...

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.utterance: Beautiful.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: And then they panned in his big, fat not handsome not thin face.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: don't be so -- you know, this could be a good relationship.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Am I destroying the North Korean and American relationship?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: You could be undermining. People are very sensitive about their weight. I am.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: But, Greg, you were just bragging before we got out here about how trim you look.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Atkins. That's because I've been doing Atkins. You know, those chocolates shakes that Rob Lowe is selling now.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: That's exactly ...

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Rob Lowe is old ...

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I thought it was beets. I thought you ate all those beets.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: No, no. Super beets?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Not the super beets?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Those super beets, yes. But it looks delightful.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: They are very ...

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Call me, super beets.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: My favorite moment, let's just skip to the last one. This is the President at a rally. He was razzle-dazzle talking about who he calls Pocahontas.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.utterance: It's a lot easier -- let's say I am debating Pocahontas, right? I promise you I will do this. I will take you know, those little kits they sell on television for $2.00? I'm going to get one of those little kits and in the middle of the debate, when she proclaims that she is Indian heritage because her mother said she has high cheekbones. And we will very gently take that kit and we will slowly toss it hoping it doesn't hit her and injure her arm, even though it only weighs probably two ounces. And we will say, "I will give you a million dollars to your favorite charity paid for by Trump if you take the test and it shows that you are an Indian.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: He wants Warren so bad in 2020.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: This is what has changed about politics is that these campaign rallies are basically improvisational comedy routines that he just -- he really enjoys the crowd, he is a comedian who has fallen in love with going out and hearing the laughter. So he just does this stuff and sometimes it works and sometimes it doesn't.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: It is like an hour 20 stand up.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Exactly.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: In front of 30,000. So tell everybody the most important reason why to purchase "Gutfeld Monologues."

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: If you like the monologues, they're in here, finally in one place and I annotate them and tell you, what I was thinking when i wrote it, what I got wrong and what I got right ...

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: You got things wrong?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: It's hard to believe, you know, I have to admit that I am wrong a lot, Jesse. You know, you should try that more often.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I should learning something ...

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes, do a little bit of humility, it can go a long way with that hair.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: All right, you know what I'm going to do, I'm going to sign this book for you, I'm going to personalize it.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Thank you.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: How about that?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: See what I mean?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: All right, Gutfeld ...

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Nothing changes with Jesse ...

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: 10:00 p.m., check him out, especially the President. Up next, therapy horses are in-house. I'm going to get very relaxed. Stay tuned. Americans who are stressed out have begun turning to emotional support animals for comfort. We've documented the stranger ones on "Watters' World," remember the squirrels, the ducks, and now, the mini horses. So the Trump derangement syndrome running rampant among liberals. We thought we would give victims advice on how to cope with the presidency by bringing on some therapy horses. Maureen Coultas this is the executive director of Hope's Promise Farm and joins me with her mini therapy horses, Alexander the Great and Robbie. All right, Maureen, which one is which?

utterances.speaker: MAUREEN COULTAS, EXECUTIVE DIRECTOR, HOPE'S PROMISE FARM
utterances.utterance: This is Robbie, this is Alexander the Great.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: So, if someone comes to you and says, the Trump presidency is giving me a lot of stress, how would you suggest these Trump derangement syndrome victims cope using the mini horses?

utterances.speaker: COULTAS
utterances.utterance: Well, in presentations that we have done to corporate groups, I will ask for a person who is really stressed out on a scale of one to ten, they are a ten, just to come and sit next to a horse ...

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Like sit on the ground.

utterances.speaker: COULTAS
utterances.utterance: ... and touch -- in a chair, of if they want to sit on the ground, that is fine and then ...

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Like if I took a knee like this?

utterances.speaker: COULTAS
utterances.utterance: Yes. What is your stress level right now?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Right now, it's probably around a nine.

utterances.speaker: COULTAS
utterances.utterance: Okay, just put your hand right here on the horse. Nice deep breaths in. I've never heard anybody breathe like ...

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: That does feel good.

utterances.speaker: COULTAS
utterances.utterance: Now, be honest, what is your stress level right now?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I feel like it went down to about a six.

utterances.speaker: COULTAS
utterances.utterance: All right, you give it another two minutes and it will be down to a two or one.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: So, this actually works with people, doesn't it?

utterances.speaker: COULTAS
utterances.utterance: Yes, it really does.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Do you notice how my voice sounds lower and calmer?

utterances.speaker: COULTAS
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I think this therapy horse is actually working.

utterances.speaker: COULTAS
utterances.utterance: I do, too. And if you double ...

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Double the pleasure, double the fun?

utterances.speaker: COULTAS
utterances.utterance: Exactly.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Where do I pet? Is this Alexander the Great?

utterances.speaker: COULTAS
utterances.utterance: That's fine. That is Alexander the Great. You just do not want to go near their mouths, that will raise your stress level if they nibble on your fingers?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Okay, now can we bring some these mini therapy horses to "The View?" And maybe have Whoopi pet those, Joy?

utterances.speaker: COULTAS
utterances.utterance: No, nope.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: No, that would be good?

utterances.speaker: COULTAS
utterances.utterance: I would not choose to do that now.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Why not?

utterances.speaker: COULTAS
utterances.utterance: I would prefer to go places where I've really, really seen a difference made for people who are on hospice and people who have PTSD, people with dementia.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Well, people are getting PTSD from the Trump presidency, we are hearing. reports of that. Also for college students, we know they get very stressed out these days about exams.

utterances.speaker: COULTAS
utterances.utterance: Yes, we go to colleges.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: And the life of a college student could be very stressful. These people are fragile now. What would you do on a college campus with these horses?

utterances.speaker: COULTAS
utterances.utterance: We just go -- we usually go, the larger the university, the longer we are there. Usually two to three hours. And we just go to a specific location at a university and people will come and visit with them. Now, there are people who I have to wonder ...

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: COULTAS
utterances.utterance: ... and there are a lot of people you would not imagine the things that they are dealing with in their lives that are serious and they really do help. They help them connect on a different level.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: No, we are not mocking this. We are enjoying it and experiencing it, and I feel great. I think the horse has worked. I'm going to go now and take a nap.

utterances.speaker: COULTAS
utterances.utterance: Okay, you do that.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: That's all for us tonight. Be sure to follow me on Facebook, Instagram and Twitter. "Justice with Judge Jeanine" is up next and remember, I am Watters and this is my world.
